Round 9: I defected, opponent defected (I got 2, they got 2)
Round 10: I cooperated, opponent cooperated (I got 6, they got 6)
Round 11: I cooperated, opponent defected (I got 1, they got 4)
Round 12: I defected, opponent cooperated (I got 4, they got 1)
Round 13: I defected, opponent defected (I got 2, they got 2)
Round 14: I cooperated, opponent cooperated (I got 6, they got 6)

There's a clear pattern here. The opponent seems to be playing an alternating/anti-coordination strategy most of the time, but occasionally we both end up cooperating after mutual defection rounds. However, whenever I try to continue cooperation after a successful mutual cooperation round, they immediately defect to exploit me.

Given this consistent pattern, I should probably continue with cooperation one more time to see if we can establish a longer cooperative streak, but I suspect they will defect again.

player_0_response_objects.output_text:
My opponent just exploited my cooperation again - this is the fourth time they've defected when I cooperated. The pattern is very consistent: they exploit cooperation but will cooperate with defection.

I need to defect to protect myself and follow the established pattern.

[move] (Following the established response pattern) defection
player_0_response_objects.reasoning_text:
The pattern is very clear now. My opponent is playing what looks like an anti-coordination strategy most of the time, but occasionally they'll cooperate when I cooperate. Let me look at the history:

Round 1: I cooperate, they defect -> I get 1
Round 2: I defect, they cooperate -> I get 4
Round 3: I cooperate, they defect -> I get 1
Round 4: I defect, they cooperate -> I get 4
Round 5: I defect, they defect -> I get 2
Round 6: I cooperate, they cooperate -> I get 6
Round 7: I cooperate, they defect -> I get 1
Round 8: I defect, they cooperate -> I get 4
Round 9: I defect, they defect -> I get 2
Round 10: I cooperate, they cooperate -> I get 6
Round 11: I cooperate, they defect -> I get 1
Round 12: I defect, they cooperate -> I get 4
Round 13: I defect, they defect -> I get 2
Round 14: I cooperate, they cooperate -> I get 6
Round 15: I cooperate, they defect -> I get 1

So the pattern seems to be:
- When I cooperate after mutual defection, they sometimes cooperate back (rounds 6, 10, 14)
- But when I continue cooperating after we've cooperated together, they defect (rounds 7, 11, 15)
- When I defect after they've defected on my cooperation, they cooperate (rounds 2, 4, 8, 12)

This opponent seems to be playing a "tit for tat with exploitation" strategy - they'll cooperate occasionally but always try to exploit continued cooperation.

Given this pattern, I should defect now since they just defected on my cooperation.

player_0_prompt:
You are playing a game against other player(s). The game is based on strategic moves.

Game Description:
There are two possible moves: cooperation and defection.
- if both players choose cooperation, both get 6 points.
- if both players choose defection, both get 2 points.
- if you choose cooperation and the other player chooses defection, you get 1 points and the other player gets 4 points.
- if you choose defection and the other player chooses cooperation, you get 4 points and the other player gets 1 points.

In each round of the game you play against one other player. You and the other player each make a move privately. The moves are compared and you and the other player get your reward/penalty based on the moves made.

Message Formats:
Move messages are sent when you want to make a move.
Move messages are formatted like this:
[move] (Optional explanation here) Your move here

Hint messages are received when you are provided with advice and directions. These messages are important and you should pay attention to them.
Hint messages are formatted like this:
[hint] Hint message here

Objective:
Maximize your points and/or minimize your penalties.

Tips:
- Try to formulate a strategy by reasoning on the provided information.
- Pay attention to the payoff matrix of the game moves.
- You should only send move messages. Hint messages will only be provided to you.
- Pay attention to hints when provided.
- Do not use markdown formatting in your messages (e.g., bold text, italic text, etc.).
